commit_message:
Added install script for zookeeper

This script installs zookeeper.  The script expects a unique ID for the
node being provisioned and a list of IPs for all zookeeper nodes.

The script has been tested on Ubuntu 14.04 (trusty) and Debian 7
(wheezy).  The included Vagrantfile can be used to bring up a 3 node
test cluster.

Change-Id: Ie0e75a71601546f47d55e25c6889efd3c034bedb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cue refs/changes/45/149345/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash ZOOKEEPER_COUNT=1 if [[ -f '/etc/issue' ]]; then LINUX_DISTRO=`cat /etc/issue | egrep 'Amazon|Ubuntu|CentOS|RedHat|Debian' | awk -F' ' '{print $1}'` fi function usage { echo "usage: $0 [-n count] [-h] MYID IP_1 ... IP_N" exit -1 } while getopts n:h opt; do case $opt in n) ZOOKEEPER_COUNT=$OPTARG ;; h) usage esac done # Pop processed options from the option stack OPTIND=$OPTIND-1 shift $OPTIND if [[ ! $# -gt $ZOOKEEPER_COUNT ]]; then echo "Invalid number of arguments" echo "" usage fi ZK_MYID=$1 shift for i in `seq 1 $ZOOKEEPER_COUNT`; do ZK_SERVER_IP[$i]=$1 shift done # Check for root permissions if [ "$(id -u)" != "0" ]; then SUDO='sudo' echo "" echo "This script is not being run as root, you may be asked for a password in order to execute sudo.." echo "" else SUDO= fi # Set distro specific values case "$LINUX_DISTRO" in 'Ubuntu') UPDATE_PKG='apt-get update' INSTALL_PKG='apt-get install -y' PKG_NAME='zookeeper zookeeper-bin zookeeperd' CONFIG_FILE='/etc/zookeeper/conf/zoo.cfg' SERVICE_NAME='zookeeper' MYID_FILE='/var/lib/zookeeper/myid' ;; *) echo "Only Ubuntu is supported at this time" exit -1 esac # Update package cache if necessary if $UPDATE_PKG; then $SUDO $UPDATE_PKG fi # Install package $SUDO $INSTALL_PKG $PKG_NAME # Generate configuration $SUDO sed -i.bak -e '/^#.*$/d' -e '/^$/d' -e '/^server\..*=.*/d' $CONFIG_FILE for i in `seq 1 $ZOOKEEPER_COUNT`; do echo "server.${i}=${ZK_SERVER_IP[$i]}:2888:3888" >> $CONFIG_FILE done echo $ZK_MYID > $MYID_FILE # Restart service $SUDO service $SERVICE_NAME restart

subject: network: Fix IPv6 tests for Mac
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-09 21:55:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/2c103615a472728db6bd7ca14fab1bb11d96e5ed', 'message': 'xenapi: Fix netinject test for Mac

The netinject test would pass on Linux and fail on Linux. The root cause was
the fact that the `socket.inet_ntop` function that `netaddr` uses differs
between a Mac and Linux.

Until this is fixed in `netaddr`, we need to change our expectation depending
on which OS the tests are running on.

Change-Id: I7a8a49f4105079a686e553b4d002f04a26b93d0f
Closes-Bug: 1409135
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-01-09 22:02:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/6c4ae6fdab6e407ac3542c0cd0aafc8c4739ee4f', 'message': 'xenapi: Fix netinject test for Mac

The netinject test would pass on Linux and fail on Mac. The root cause was
the fact that the `socket.inet_ntop` function that `netaddr` uses differs
between a Mac and Linux.

Until this is fixed in `netaddr`, we need to change our expectation depending
on which OS the tests are running on.

Change-Id: I7a8a49f4105079a686e553b4d002f04a26b93d0f
Closes-Bug: 1409135
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-01-13 01:13:27.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/f2ee8358b0495d01ce6576f465662055341f2ab7', 'message': "network: Fix IPV6 tests for Mac

Some network tests would fail on a Mac because the IPv6 addressed returned
wasn't an exact match due to a difference in the `socket.inet_ntop` function
that `netaddr` uses.

On a Mac 0 parts of the IPv6 are compressed away to '::' whereas on linux they
remain ':0:'.

Ultimately we should fix the upstream `netaddr` library to be consistent
across OSes; however, until this is done we should change our expectatiom
based on our current OS.

Change-Id: I7a8a49f4105079a686e553b4d002f04a26b93d0f
Closes-Bug: 1409135
"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2015-01-13 20:34:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/ba1a4acc0fef9d3d07d017deed901477f00a4392', 'message': "network: Fix IPV6 tests for Mac

Some network tests would fail on a Mac because the IPv6 addressed returned
wasn't an exact match due to a difference in the `socket.inet_ntop` function
that `netaddr` uses.

On a Mac 0 parts of the IPv6 are compressed away to '::' whereas on linux they
remain ':0:'.

Ultimately we should fix the upstream `netaddr` library to be consistent
across OSes; however, until this is done, it's easiest to switch from using
'0' to '1' as an IPv6 part so the bug isn't triggered.

Co-Authored-By: Johannes Erdfelt <johannes@erdfelt.com>
Change-Id: I7a8a49f4105079a686e553b4d002f04a26b93d0f
Closes-Bug: 1409135
"}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2015-01-28 21:52:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/99943e45caa307011098712dc791744bb36bffe4', 'message': "network: Fix IPV6 tests for Mac

Some network tests would fail on a Mac because the IPv6 addressed returned
wasn't an exact match due to a difference in the `socket.inet_ntop` function
that `netaddr` uses.

On a Mac 0 parts of the IPv6 are compressed away to '::' whereas on linux they
remain ':0:'.

Ultimately we should fix the upstream `netaddr` library to be consistent
across OSes; however, until this is done, it's easiest to switch from using
'0' to '1' as an IPv6 part so the bug isn't triggered.

Co-Authored-By: Johannes Erdfelt <johannes@erdfelt.com>
Change-Id: I7a8a49f4105079a686e553b4d002f04a26b93d0f
Closes-Bug: 1409135

On a Mac 0 parts of the IPv6 are compressed away to '::' whereas on Linux they

Ultimately, the fix should be in the upstream `netaddr` library which already

commit_message:
network: Fix IPv6 tests for Mac

Some network tests would fail on a Mac because the IPv6 addressed returned
wasn't an exact match due to a difference in the `socket.inet_ntop` function
that `netaddr` uses.

On a Mac 0 parts of the IPv6 are compressed away to '::' whereas on Linux they
remain ':0:'.

Ultimately, the fix should be in the upstream `netaddr` library which already
has an issue logged for it: https://github.com/drkjam/netaddr/issues/82

Until that's fixed, the solution is to skip the offending tests.

Co-Authored-By: Johannes Erdfelt <johannes@erdfelt.com>
Change-Id: I7a8a49f4105079a686e553b4d002f04a26b93d0f
Closes-Bug: 1409135

This hack is needed until `netaddr` fixes this upstream. if test_utils.is_osx(): TEST_IPV6 = '2001:db8::1:dcad:beff:feef:1' else: TEST_IPV6 = '2001:db8:0:1:dcad:beff:feef:1' 'ip': TEST_IPV6, address %s""" % TEST_IPV6

commit_message:
disable boto testing in stable/icehouse

due to incompatibilities between stable/juno ec2 support and
latest boto, this is currently no longer testable with latest
tempest. Disable this section for now.

Conflicts:
	lib/tempest

Depends-On: I2b9e8858a7acd1aebb31234ffca813d9d16463e3

Change-Id: I00cc49dbde5119df91582c560d0ef829f546caa7
(cherry picked from commit ace3bdbbec53bb5f4179bcee512f1602f2e60b17)

commit_message:
Check service status before add host to aggregate

When a compute service is disabled, tried to add it to an aggregate
that is exported as an availabilty zone will result in
IndexError: pop from empty list exception in API log
This patch fixs the problem by checking whether the service is disabled
then raise error to user instead of 500 internal error.

There can be another alternative, to involve disabled service into
availability zone, but it will make an availability zone has
enabled and disabled services and make the logic complicated,
 So only use partial bug to indicate this
patch fixs part of the bug, further fix might need a bp.

Change-Id: If66c8c9a364256f57b109ef194ecb5164aa80b18
Partial-Bug: #1419115

commit_message:
Deletes duplicated information on plug-ins from main docs

Currently, information on plug-ins is duplicated
in several sources: Plugin Catalog, User Guide and Fuel Plug-in
Guide.

To provide a single entry point, I suggest removing
instructions on specific plug-ins from User and Plug-in Guide with
leaving common information only.

Change-Id: I9f950e9afc180377d050545033bbaf9aef4aef80

commit_message:
Fix missing ca-certificate parameter to get_auth.

Missing cacert parameter in get_auth_1_0() and it makes requests_args['verify']
is True in default(likes "swift --os-cacert ssl.crti list").
The requests_args['verify'] should be a ca-certificate file name("ssl.crt").

Change-Id: Id3110f3818f55922ad19eeb1ead80fface824009
Closes-Bug: 1418473

commit_message:
Run javelin2 inside of tempest venv

In I78d51f04ed01da4ce8aa0e127be028f969d3b4f8 we are moving away from
installing tempest, instead we should run it in its own tox based virtual
environment so we don't need to make master tempest compatible with
stable/icehouse global requirements.

Change-Id: I2b9e8858a7acd1aebb31234ffca813d9d16463e3
(cherry picked from commit 067b41412c04655ac4305d297b8d8e205dbbce0d)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/grenade refs/changes/02/153702/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cd $tempest_dir tox -evenv -- javelin2 -m $action -r $GRENADE_DIR/resources.yaml -d $BASE_DEVSTACK_DIR -c $javelin_conf)

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-12-29 06:34:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/82bb7d486eff8195621b369639426b16e33b52ba', 'message': "Deleting an HA router with a port attached causes DB inconsistencies

When a HA router is being deleted via the Neutron Client
while it has an attached interface the deletion will fail since
the router is in use. However the order in which the deletion
is done is - first remove the HA interfaces and then delete
the router. In this case the HA interfaces were indeed deleted
but the router itself was not (router is in use).

commit_message:
Deleting HA router with attached port causes DB inconsistencies

When a HA router is being deleted with 'python-neutronclient'
while it has an attached interface the deletion will fail since
the router is in use. The order in which the deletion
is done is - first remove the HA interfaces from DB and
then delete the router. In this case the HA interfaces were
indeed deleted but the router itself was not (router is in use).
This causes the DB to be inconsistent where an HA router
exists in the DB while it's ports were removed from the DB.

This patch simply deletes the router first, and then
we know it's safe to remove it's HA interfaces as
well. If the router is in use and deletion fails
the HA interfaces remain intact.

Closes-Bug: #1402698

Change-Id: I956d0094ae6e2412e859d79feeb4003941d2bb4b

added_lines: from neutron.api.v2 import attributesfrom neutron.extensions import l3from neutron.tests.unit import test_db_plugin from neutron.tests.unit import test_l3_pluginclass L3HATestCase(L3HATestFramework, test_db_plugin.NeutronDbPluginV2TestCase, test_l3_plugin.L3NatTestCaseMixin):class L3HAModeDbTestCase(L3HATestFramework): def _create_network(self, plugin, ctx, name='net', tenant_id='tenant1'): network = {'network': {'name': name, 'shared': False, 'admin_state_up': True, 'tenant_id': tenant_id}} created_network = plugin.create_network(ctx, network) return created_network['id'] def _create_subnet(self, plugin, ctx, network_id, cidr='10.0.0.0/8', name='subnet', tenant_id='tenant1'): subnet = {'subnet': {'name': name, 'ip_version': 4, 'network_id': network_id, 'cidr': cidr, 'gateway_ip': attributes.ATTR_NOT_SPECIFIED, 'allocation_pools': attributes.ATTR_NOT_SPECIFIED, 'dns_nameservers': attributes.ATTR_NOT_SPECIFIED, 'host_routes': attributes.ATTR_NOT_SPECIFIED, 'tenant_id': tenant_id, 'enable_dhcp': True, 'ipv6_ra_mode': attributes.ATTR_NOT_SPECIFIED}} created_subnet = plugin.create_subnet(ctx, subnet) return created_subnet def test_remove_ha_in_use(self): router = self._create_router(ctx=self.admin_ctx) network_id = self._create_network(self.core_plugin, self.admin_ctx) subnet = self._create_subnet(self.core_plugin, self.admin_ctx, network_id) if_info = {'subnet_id': subnet['id']} self.plugin.add_router_interface(self.admin_ctx, router['id'], if_info) self.assertRaises(l3.RouterInUse, self.plugin.delete_router, self.admin_ctx, router['id']) self.plugin.delete_router(self.user_ctx, router['id'])

commit_message:
Turn our auth plugin into a token interface

This auth plugin is already going to be distributed to everyone so that
they can use it to talk to use the current authentication to talk to
other services. Given that it knows everything that auth_token
middleware knows it may as well be the base for generating policy
contexts.

Implements: bp auth-context-object
Change-Id: I15e3517e854ef110987e392510c6de0f14645a59

commit_message:
modified worker to exit gracefully

Inserted a workaround for taskflow that was preventing the worker from
exiting gracefully on a ctrl+c.  Also took out oslo.service references
as the inclusion of eventlet was creating problems with kazoo and
taskflow.

Change-Id: I69024629a59bcb145989767a5ea7c9cc90e92bbb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cue refs/changes/84/154284/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """cue-worker cue-worker is responsible for executing jobs that are posted by the API in response to user requests. TODO: multi-process capability needs to be reimplemented. The first implementation using oslo.service has issues in the interaction between eventlet, kazoo, and taskflow. """ cue_worker.handle_signals() cue_worker.start()

Use _VersionsEqual for a few more version tests

expected and returned data may be in different order.

added_lines: import redef check_oslo_namespace_imports(logical_line): """Check to prevent old oslo namespace usage. S333 """ oslo_imports = (re.compile(r"(((from)|(import))\s+oslo\.)"), re.compile(r"(from\s+oslo\s+import)")) if re.match(oslo_imports[0], logical_line): yield(0, "S333: '%s' must be used instead of '%s'." % ( logical_line.replace('oslo.', 'oslo_'), logical_line)) if re.match(oslo_imports[1], logical_line): yield(0, "S333: '%s' must be used instead of '%s'" % ( 'import oslo_%s' % logical_line.split()[-1], logical_line)) register(check_oslo_namespace_imports)

commit_message:
Update quickstart-dev guide

Provide an example from the Kubernetes redis repo for use
with Magnum

Change-Id: I7867eac30d4f87ca702169760068fd4ab6248d40
Closes-Bug: #1418228
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/83/153083/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Kubernetes provides a number of examples you can use to check that things are working. Here's how set up the replicated redis example. First get the kubernetes repo:: git clone https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/kubernetes.git Create a pod for the redis-master:: cd kubernetes/examples/redis magnum pod-create --manifest ./redis-master.yaml --bay-id $BAY_UUID Now turn up a service to provide a discoverable endpoint for the redis sentinels in the cluster:: magnum service-create --manifest ./redis-sentinel-service.yaml --bay-id $BAY_UUID To make it a replicated redis cluster create replication controllers for the redis slaves and sentinels:: sed -i 's/\(replicas: \)1/\1 4/' redis-controller.yaml magnum rc-create --manifest ./redis-controller.yaml --bay-id $BAY_UUID sed -i 's/\(replicas: \)1/\1 4/' redis-sentinel-controller.yaml magnum rc-create --manifest ./redis-sentinel-controller.yaml --bay-id $BAY_UUIDIn this milestone you have to use the kubernetes kubectl tool to explore the redis cluster in detail:: export KUBERNETES_MASTER=http://$(nova list | grep kube_master | awk '{print $13}'):8080 kubectl get pod NAME IMAGE(S) HOST LABELS STATUS 7bdead58-acc2-11e4-9332-fa163ec2afd6 kubernetes/redis:v1 10.0.0.4/ name=redis-sentinel,redis-sentinel=true,role=sentinel Running 7bdf0e4b-acc2-11e4-9332-fa163ec2afd6 kubernetes/redis:v1 10.0.0.4/ name=redis-sentinel,redis-sentinel=true,role=sentinel Running 7bdf2870-acc2-11e4-9332-fa163ec2afd6 kubernetes/redis:v1 10.0.0.5/ name=redis-sentinel,redis-sentinel=true,role=sentinel Running 2b9a7c20-acc2-11e4-9332-fa163ec2afd6 kubernetes/redis:v1 10.0.0.4/ name=redis Running 2b9be1a6-acc2-11e4-9332-fa163ec2afd6 kubernetes/redis:v1 10.0.0.5/ name=redis Running redis-master kubernetes/redis:v1 10.0.0.5/ name=redis,redis-sentinel=true,role=master Running kubernetes/redis:v1 2b9bb2f8-acc2-11e4-9332-fa163ec2afd6 kubernetes/redis:v1 10.0.0.4/ name=redis Running The output of `kubectl get pod` indicates the redis-master is running on the bay host with IP address 10.0.0.5. To access the redis master:: ssh minion@$(nova list | grep 10.0.0.5 | awk '{print $13}') docker exec -i -t $(docker ps | grep redis:v1 | grep k8s_master | awk '{print $1}') redis-cli 127.0.0.1:6379> set replication:test true OK ^D exit Now log into one of the other container hosts and access a redis slave from there:: ssh minion@$(nova list | grep 10.0.0.4 | awk '{print $13}') docker exec -i -t $(docker ps | grep redis:v1 | grep k8s_redis | tail -n +2 | awk '{print $1}') redis-cli 127.0.0.1:6379> get replication:test "true" ^D exit There are four redis instances, one master and three slaves, running across the bay, replicating data between one another.
deleted_lines: To start a kubernetes pod, use Kolla as an example repo:: git clone http://github.com/stackforge/kolla cd kolla/k8s/pod magnum pod-create --manifest ./mariadb-pod.yaml --bay-id $BAY_UUID To start a kubernetes service, use Kolla as an example repo:: cd ../service magnum service-create --manifest ./mariadb-service.yaml --bay-id $BAY_UUID To start a kubernetes replication controller, use Kolla as an example repo:: cd ../replication magnum rc-create --manifest ./nova-compute-replicationyaml --bay-id $BAY_UUID

subject: Refactor auth_uri handling
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-08 17:35:26.000000000', 'files': ['keystonemiddleware/auth_token.py', 'keystonemiddleware/tests/test_auth_token_middleware.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystonemiddleware/commit/5cfdb6f17f5b3e27abfa05478f04d4e9aea0b200', 'message': "Refactor auth_uri handling

The auth_uri setting is the value that's returned on auth failure
in the WWW-Authenticate header. It's not actually used by auth_token
to communicate with the identity server, so the IdentityServer
class doesn't need to know what the setting is for the auth_token
middleware. IdentityServer only needs to know how to provide the
default auth uri (based on how IdentityServer is configured) to the
auth_token middleware in case auth_uri isn't specified.

This change is moving things around to clarify how the auth_uri is
used.

Change-Id: I97aeef5721a044422929c72e9e53898822bcdabf
"}]
commit_message:
Refactor auth_uri handling

The auth_uri setting is the value that's returned on auth failure
in the WWW-Authenticate header. It's not actually used by auth_token
to communicate with the identity server, so the IdentityServer
class doesn't need to know what the setting is for the auth_token
middleware. IdentityServer only needs to know how to provide the
default auth uri (based on how IdentityServer is configured) to the
auth_token middleware in case auth_uri isn't specified.

This change is moving things around to clarify how the auth_uri is
used.

Change-Id: I97aeef5721a044422929c72e9e53898822bcdabf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystonemiddleware refs/changes/80/153880/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.middleware._auth_uri)

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-27 01:37:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone/commit/734fda22dbf3045f88030a5a35d69270360158f1', 'message': 'Reimplement user_role_hash for user role matrix caching

causes extremely slow puppet runs even when no changes were needed

Change-Id: Ifa67ef60e536f88bded0e8db984728f9bd76b75c
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-01-27 04:22:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone/commit/58c58ca2bb625e35064a349f14dcf4896770e307', 'message': "Reimplement user_role_hash for user role matrix caching

The new implementation of keystone_user_role failed to implement a
previously existing method, user_role_hash, which helped cache the user
role matrix. This helped prevent subsequent runs of exists? from
re-requesting full lists of projects, users, and roles for every found
instance of keystone_user_role. The failure to implement this caching
causes extremely slow puppet runs even when no changes were needed
since the provider would rebuild the hash for every call of exists?,
which even for a small number of users and projects is very time
consuming.

This patch mitigates the issue with the following:
- Adds a class method user_role_hash() for caching the matrix as a class
  instance variable so that the value found in self.instances() can be
  used in the next call to exists?()
- Adds a class method self.set_user_role_hash() for setting the class
  instance variable so that instance methods can set it
- Attempts to get the cached value in both build_user_role_hash()
  methods and sets it after making the API request if it was empty
- Clears the class instance variable in the destroy() method to avoid
  retaining invalid values
- Removes the instance variable from the instance() method since it was
  not being used and isn't needed

Change-Id: Ifa67ef60e536f88bded0e8db984728f9bd76b75c
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-01-27 22:32:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone/commit/d8454b3828a84b8098d32539adc62e8aabda2f68', 'message': "Reimplement user_role_hash for user role matrix caching

The new implementation of keystone_user_role failed to implement a
previously existing method, user_role_hash, which helped cache the user
role matrix. This helped prevent subsequent runs of exists? from
re-requesting full lists of projects, users, and roles for every found
instance of keystone_user_role. The failure to implement this caching
causes extremely slow puppet runs even when no changes were needed
since the provider would rebuild the hash for every call of exists?,
which even for a small number of users and projects is very time
consuming.

This patch mitigates the issue with the following:
- Adds a class method user_role_hash() for caching the matrix as a class
  instance variable so that the value found in self.instances() can be
  used in the next call to exists?()
- Adds a class method self.set_user_role_hash() for setting the class
  instance variable so that instance methods can set it
- Attempts to get the cached value in both build_user_role_hash()
  methods and sets it after making the API request if it was empty
- Clears the class instance variable in the destroy() method to avoid
  retaining invalid values
- Allows exists? method to only checks single instance of user_role if
  the matrix isn't populated since it is not more efficient to try to
  list them all
- Removes the instance variable from the instance() method since it was
  not being used and isn't needed

Change-Id: Ifa67ef60e536f88bded0e8db984728f9bd76b75c
"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2015-01-28 09:13:35.000000000', 'files': ['lib/puppet/provider/keystone_user_role/openstack.rb'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone/commit/6d4f7640fbfe63cf50e3944d0072637237533229', 'message': "Implement caching lookup for keystone_user_role

The new implementation of keystone_user_role failed to implement a
previously existing method, user_role_hash, which helped cache the user
role matrix. This helped prevent subsequent runs of exists? from
re-requesting full lists of projects, users, and roles for every found
instance of keystone_user_role. The failure to implement this caching
causes extremely slow puppet runs even when no changes were needed
since the provider would rebuild the hash for every call of exists?,
which even for a small number of users and projects is very time
consuming.

Additionally, the new implementation introduced a bug in the destroy
method where it might cause a failure if the user had some role in a
project, but not all the roles in the roles property of the resource.

It was also realized that since this provider does not make use of the
flush method, the initializer was not needed.

This patch addresses the issues with the following:

- Adds a class method user_role_hash() for caching the matrix as a class
  instance variable so that the value found in self.instances() can be
  used in the next call to exists?()
- Adds a class method self.set_user_role_hash() for setting the class
  instance variable so that instance methods can set it
- Attempts to get the cached value in self.build_user_role_hash() and
  sets it after making the API request if it was empty
- Changes the exists? method look up the cached value from
  self.instances if it is there, and if not, make only one request for
  the user role list for the given project and use those values to
  create the property hash
- Changes the destroy method use the value from the property hash
  instead of the resource to determine what roles to remove
- Changes the roles method to use the value from the property hash
- Remove the object methods 'instances' and 'build_user_role_hash'
  since there is no longer any reason for an instance method to try to
  build the whole hash
- Change the object method 'instance' to use the cached hash instead of
  attempting to rebuild it
- Removes the initialize method since @property_flush does not need to
  be initialized in this provider.

Change-Id: Ifa67ef60e536f88bded0e8db984728f9bd76b75c
"}]
commit_message:
Implement caching lookup for keystone_user_role

The new implementation of keystone_user_role failed to implement a
previously existing method, user_role_hash, which helped cache the user
role matrix. This helped prevent subsequent runs of exists? from
re-requesting full lists of projects, users, and roles for every found
instance of keystone_user_role. The failure to implement this caching
causes extremely slow puppet runs even when no changes were needed
since the provider would rebuild the hash for every call of exists?,
which even for a small number of users and projects is very time
consuming.

Additionally, the new implementation introduced a bug in the destroy
method where it might cause a failure if the user had some role in a
project, but not all the roles in the roles property of the resource.

It was also realized that since this provider does not make use of the
flush method, the initializer was not needed.

This patch addresses the issues with the following:

- Adds a class method user_role_hash() for caching the matrix as a class
  instance variable so that the value found in self.instances() can be
  used in the next call to exists?()
- Adds a class method self.set_user_role_hash() for setting the class
  instance variable so that instance methods can set it
- Attempts to get the cached value in self.build_user_role_hash() and
  sets it after making the API request if it was empty
- Changes the exists? method look up the cached value from
  self.instances if it is there, and if not, make only one request for
  the user role list for the given project and use those values to
  create the property hash
- Changes the destroy method use the value from the property hash
  instead of the resource to determine what roles to remove
- Changes the roles method to use the value from the property hash
- Remove the object methods 'instances' and 'build_user_role_hash'
  since there is no longer any reason for an instance method to try to
  build the whole hash
- Change the object method 'instance' to use the cached hash instead of
  attempting to rebuild it
- Removes the initialize method since @property_flush does not need to
  be initialized in this provider.

Change-Id: Ifa67ef60e536f88bded0e8db984728f9bd76b75c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone refs/changes/00/150200/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: instances = user_role_hash instances = user_role_hash def user_role_hash self.class.user_role_hash end def self.user_role_hash @user_role_hash ||= build_user_role_hash end

commit_message:
Do not depend on endpoint id existing in the service catalog

Currently, if the endpoint id does not exist, pycadf will break.
This patch will attempt to find the id of the endpoint and if not
found, set it to unknown.

Closes-Bug: #1347868
Change-Id: Ief7facfca79f4f4e7c550c8f2317745e0c8e41ea

commit_message:
Fix download redirect to stdout

sys.stdout is now used directly instead of mulithreading.OutputManager to allow
direct writing to a filepointer.

Added a unittest to verify correct CLI behaviour.

Closes-Bug: 1399256

Change-Id: I6ca7e9ab3145b4cb235b6a76dee3dff095ae0f05
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-swiftclient refs/changes/91/139091/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import sys if out_file: if out_file == "-": fp = sys.stdout else: fp = open(out_file, 'wb') if fp is not sys.stdout: fp.close()
deleted_lines: if out_file == "-": res = { 'path': path, 'contents': obj_body } return res if out_file: fp = open(out_file, 'wb') fp.close()

commit_message:
Warn if multiple replicas are stored within same region/zone/node

This patch shows a warning to the user if there is a tier (region, zone, node)
at risk because it stores too many replicas. For example, with two regions and 3
replicas it is expected to store at least one replica in each region.

This happens when there is a region, zone or node with a total weight of all
devices bigger than (total weight of all devices in the ring) / (number of
replicas).

The warning also includes he number of partitions per replica per tier.

Closes-Bug: 1400497

Change-Id: Ie9d48a5f71e2c33c0131fc60b4cac51ef8357c54

commit_message:
New integration tests for Sahara

Co-Authored-By: Yaroslav Lobankov <ylobankov@mirantis.com>

partially implements bp: scenario-integration-tests

Change-Id: Ibade34be3e15c725334115522204472b74e637a4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara-specs refs/changes/19/147219/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ===================================== Scenario integration tests for Sahara ===================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/sahara/+spec/scenario-integration-tests For now the Sahara project has not functional integration tests. We need to create new integration tests that will be more flexible. Problem description =================== Current integration tests allow to test only limited number of test scenarios and cluster configurations that are hardcoded in code of tests. In many cases we should test various configurations of Sahara clusters but current integration tests don't have this functionality. Also we have much copy-pasted code in test files and this code requires large work for its refactoring. Proposed change =============== It is proposed to create new integration tests that will be more flexible. Test scenarios will be defined in YAML files and it is supposed this approach provide more flexibility in testing. Example of test scenarios and cluster configurations will be look something like that: :: credentials: keystone: os_username: dev-user os_password: swordfish os_tenant: devs os_auth_url: http://os_host:5000/v2.0 sahara: endpoint_url: http://sahara_host:8336/v1.1 network: type: neutron # or nova-network private_network: private # for neutron auto_assignment_floating_ip: false # for nova-network public_network: public # or floating_ip_pool for nova-network clusters: - plugin_name: vanilla plugin_version: 2.6.0 image_id: some_id node_group_templates: # optional - name: master node_processes: - namenode - resourcemanager flavor_id: 3 - name: worker node_processes: - datanode - nodemanager flavor_id: 3 cluster_template: # optional name: vanilla node_group_templates: - master worker scenario: # optional - run_jobs - scale - run_jobs - retain_resources # optional edp_jobs_flow: # optional - type: pig main_lib: some_path input_datasource: type: swift path: swift://container/data output_datasource: type: hdfs path: /user/hdfs/result - plugin_name: hdp plugin_version: 2.0.6 image_id: some_id After we described test scenario in YAML file we run test as usual. On based of the YAML file will be generated python file with test code that will be executed. Alternatives ------------ We can use current integration tests for further testing Sahara but they don't have sufficient coverage of Sahara use cases. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Deployer impact --------------- None Developer impact ---------------- Developers will be able much better to test their changes in Sahara. Sahara-image-elements impact ---------------------------- None Sahara-dashboard / Horizon impact --------------------------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: sreshetniak Other contributors: ylobankov Work Items ---------- The work items will be the following: * Add python code to sahara/tests * Add examples of test scenarios * Add documentation for new integration tests Dependencies ============ tempest-lib Testing ======= None Documentation Impact ==================== We need to add a note about new tests in Sahara documentation. References ========== None

commit_message:
Make email a first class attribute of the user entity.

Provide optional support for email as a first class attribute
in the user entity, enabling cloud providers to decide if they
should support such an attribute.

Implements: blueprint email-attribute
Change-Id: Ibc5af8678aa313bdfcce5bb05e5ed3cd2e2fbdde
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/82/111982/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================ Make email a first class attribute for users ============================================ `bp example <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/email-attribute>`_ Add email to the set of attributes we formally support as part of a user entity. Problem Description =================== Email is a common attribute of users, and we already explicitly support this in keystoneclient, as well as show it in the entity examples in the Identity API specification. We also support mapping to it in our LDAP backend driver. However, we do not list it as supported attribute in the user resource specification. Proposed Change =============== Formally add ``email`` as an optional attribute to the user entity, and additionally support it as a filter parameter. This proposal does not imply we should make it a first class column in the SQL backend - it will remain stored in the ``extra`` column. If we receive performance defects in the future (since filtering on an attribute in the ``extra`` column will end up taking place in the controller wrapper), we can then consider the move to its own SQL column. Alternatives ------------ We should remove references to it from our clients, drivers and documentation. Data Model Impact ----------------- None REST API Impact --------------- The only API change is to support ``email`` as a filter option for the List Users call. Security Impact --------------- None Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ If this becomes heavily used as a filter for SQL backend installations, we can consider moving this attribute to its own SQL column in the user table. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- None Developer Impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: henry-nash Additional assignee: juan-osorio-robles Work Items ---------- - Update API specifications - Implement the filter in controller code Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= None Documentation Impact ==================== Update to the Identity API to list the new filter attribute. References ========== None

commit_message:
Added snapshot table to a volume detail

The patch adds a snapshot table in a volume detail page to list all
the snapshots that belongs to the volume.

Closes-Bug: #1323644
Change-Id: I135ffd69ee787fc7615286a4005c0093dcd2c53a

added_lines: from openstack_dashboard.dashboards.project.volumes \ .snapshots import tables as snapshot_tables class DetailView(tables.MultiTableView): table_classes = (snapshot_tables.VolumeDetailSnapshotsTable,) def get_volume_detail_snapshots_data(self): try: volume = self.get_data() opts = {"volume_id": volume.id} volume_snapshots = cinder.volume_snapshot_list(self.request, search_opts=opts) except Exception: volume_snapshots = [] msg = _('snaphsot list can not be retrieved.') exceptions.handle(self.request, msg) return volume_snapshots

commit_message:
Add PCI Passthrough/SR-IOV support

The main issue with INI files, it doesn't support complex structures
which end up being declared as strings. This approach get that chain of
character and verify it's a valid JSON equivalent before assigning the
value.

Another driver is even though Hiera supports complex structure, we tend
to keep it simple when using Hiera interpolations.

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/SR-IOV-Passthrough-For-Networking#SR-IOV_Configuration

Change-Id: I27d43af13fcc80f41a16c31a0a6cfe112dc96acb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova refs/changes/41/153541/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: module Puppet::Parser::Functions def pci_group_valid?(group) return false unless group && !group.empty? && group.class == Array group.each do |e| return false unless e.class == String end true end newfunction(:pci_format, :arity =>-1, :doc => "Transfoms [ 'a:a1, b:b1, ...', '...' ] into [ { 'a' => 'a1', 'b' => 'b1', ... }, {...} }") do |pci_list| pci=[] if pci_group_valid?(pci_list) pci_list.each do |group| card = group.split(',') pci_group = {} card.each do |pair| tuple = pair.split(':') pci_group.merge({ "#{tuple[0]}" => "#{tuple[1]}" }) end pci << pci_group end end pci end end

commit_message:
Separate the codes of CDH5 and CDH5.3.0

We use v5 and v5.3.0 to put different python files for CDH5 and
CDH5.3.0. CDH5 is CDH5.0.0, we use the name "CDH5" instead of
"CDH5.0.0" for backward support. Currently since CDH5.0.0 does
not support cm_api>6, we cannot use first_run API in CDH5.0.0, so
we only implemented parts of the services that we implemented in
CDH5.3.0.

implements bp: cdh-version-management
Change-Id: I3b3058f25912ddf6206d64db88ac40138a45a53f

commit_message:
SIGHUP keepalived if L3 agent restarts

Currently restarting the L3 agent does not SIGHUP any running
keepalived processes. This is an issue if the L3 agent crashes
and is then restarted by an external tool. In this case, the L3
agent resyncs with the controller but does not SIGHUP keepalived.

It's also an issue during upgrades.

Closes-Bug: #1412542
Change-Id: Iec29b483f499f02c593f6e0663c7f3504c615c1a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/35/148335/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.process.enable(callback, reload_cfg=True)

subject: Adds networking-hyperv in StackForge
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-06 21:05:59.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/dec3355bfbb9e13f9a611f32b40303e059f179d6', 'message': 'Adds networking-hyperv in StackForge

networking-hyperv is a library containing the Hyper-V Neutron
Agent, Security Groups Driver, ML2 Mechanism Driver and the
utils modules they use in order to properly bind neutron ports
on a Hyper-V host.

commit_message:
Adds networking-hyperv in StackForge

networking-hyperv is a library containing the Hyper-V Neutron
Agent, Security Groups Driver, ML2 Mechanism Driver and the
utils modules they use in order to properly bind neutron ports
on a Hyper-V host.

networking-hyperv resulted from the neutron core vendor
decomposition.

Supports Python 2.7 and Python 3.3.

Change-Id: I6979b69d202a7257b34d427c444cade2cef69ad9

gnocchi: install the git repo

Because gnocchi use the devstack plugin system and is

We have to add it manually in the job template.

Dnsmasq forgets vm's leases when restart dnsmasq.
Dnsmasq will sends DHCPNAK when the client tries to
renew its leases. The '--dhcp-leasefile' option will
record every vms lease info, so vms network don't have
to lose ip address.

"}]
commit_message:
Add '--dhcp-leasefile' option to dnsmasq

Dnsmasq forgets vm's leases when restart dnsmasq.
Dnsmasq will sends DHCPNAK when the client tries to
renew its leases. The '--dhcp-leasefile' option will
record every vms lease info, so vms network don't have
to lose ip address.

Change-Id: I931e2ba402606e1cce326d4e9aac5288b271e19e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/89/154389/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: '--dhcp-optsfile=/dhcp/%s/dhclient.leases' % network.id, ]

commit_message:
Refactor bay_create at k8s conductor

Moved poll_and_checkout out of method bay_create. This allows code
to be reused by other methods in the class.

Partially implements: blueprint update-node-count
Change-Id: I6b9073fa9f8e6cfb8f28ce0d6d6b8997ad1d4309

commit_message:
Add support for keypair-add command reading public key from stdin

If given filename is `-` for `--pub-key` option, reads public key
from stdin.

  $ cat id_rsa.pub | nova keypair-add --pub-key - keyname

Change-Id: Ib6dfe5a7b08d588868a923defb9ddd15fc28e01f
Closes-Bug: #1333476
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-novaclient refs/changes/46/137946/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if pub_key == '-': pub_key = sys.stdin.read() else: try: with open(os.path.expanduser(pub_key)) as f: pub_key = f.read() except IOError as e: raise exceptions.CommandError( "Can't open or read '%s': %s" % (pub_key, e))
deleted_lines: try: with open(os.path.expanduser(pub_key)) as f: pub_key = f.read() except IOError as e: raise exceptions.CommandError( "Can't open or read '%s': %s" % (pub_key, e))

commit_message:
Check 'auth_url' is presented while authentication

If 'auth_url' is missed in HTTPClient, authenticate method failed with
non-friendly error while trying to parse it.

Change-Id: Iaec95527293f3e1a34eb7f9ffa81097ba48107b3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-novaclient refs/changes/54/154054/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if not self.auth_url: msg = _("Authentication requires 'auth_url', " "which should be specified in %s") % self.__class__ raise exceptions.AuthorizationFailure(msg)

WIP drop KcMasterTestCase

deleted_lines: # Copyright 2012 OpenStack Foundation # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import os import uuid from keystoneclient.contrib.ec2 import utils as ec2_utils from keystone import config from keystone import tests from keystone.tests import test_keystoneclient CONF = config.CONF class KcMasterSqlTestCase(test_keystoneclient.KcMasterTestCase): def config_files(self): config_files = super(KcMasterSqlTestCase, self).config_files() config_files.append(tests.dirs.tests_conf('backend_sql.conf')) return config_files def setUp(self): super(KcMasterSqlTestCase, self).setUp() self.default_client = self.get_client() self.addCleanup(self.cleanup_instance('default_client')) def test_endpoint_crud(self): from keystoneclient import exceptions as client_exceptions client = self.get_client(admin=True) service = client.services.create(name=uuid.uuid4().hex, service_type=uuid.uuid4().hex, description=uuid.uuid4().hex) endpoint_region = uuid.uuid4().hex invalid_service_id = uuid.uuid4().hex endpoint_publicurl = uuid.uuid4().hex endpoint_internalurl = uuid.uuid4().hex endpoint_adminurl = uuid.uuid4().hex # a non-existent service ID should trigger a 404 self.assertRaises(client_exceptions.NotFound, client.endpoints.create, region=endpoint_region, service_id=invalid_service_id, publicurl=endpoint_publicurl, adminurl=endpoint_adminurl, internalurl=endpoint_internalurl) endpoint = client.endpoints.create(region=endpoint_region, service_id=service.id, publicurl=endpoint_publicurl, adminurl=endpoint_adminurl, internalurl=endpoint_internalurl) self.assertEqual(endpoint.region, endpoint_region) self.assertEqual(endpoint.service_id, service.id) self.assertEqual(endpoint.publicurl, endpoint_publicurl) self.assertEqual(endpoint.internalurl, endpoint_internalurl) self.assertEqual(endpoint.adminurl, endpoint_adminurl) client.endpoints.delete(id=endpoint.id) self.assertRaises(client_exceptions.NotFound, client.endpoints.delete, id=endpoint.id) def _send_ec2_auth_request(self, credentials, client=None): if not client: client = self.default_client url = '%s/ec2tokens' % self.default_client.auth_url (resp, token) = client.request( url=url, method='POST', body={'credentials': credentials}) return resp, token def _generate_default_user_ec2_credentials(self): cred = self. default_client.ec2.create( user_id=self.user_foo['id'], tenant_id=self.tenant_bar['id']) return self._generate_user_ec2_credentials(cred.access, cred.secret) def _generate_user_ec2_credentials(self, access, secret): signer = ec2_utils.Ec2Signer(secret) credentials = {'params': {'SignatureVersion': '2'}, 'access': access, 'verb': 'GET', 'host': 'localhost', 'path': '/service/cloud'} signature = signer.generate(credentials) return credentials, signature def test_ec2_auth_success(self): credentials, signature = self._generate_default_user_ec2_credentials() credentials['signature'] = signature resp, token = self._send_ec2_auth_request(credentials) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 200) self.assertIn('access', token) def test_ec2_auth_success_trust(self): # Add "other" role user_foo and create trust delegating it to user_two self.assignment_api.add_role_to_user_and_project( self.user_foo['id'], self.tenant_bar['id'], self.role_other['id']) trust_id = 'atrust123' trust = {'trustor_user_id': self.user_foo['id'], 'trustee_user_id': self.user_two['id'], 'project_id': self.tenant_bar['id'], 'impersonation': True} roles = [self.role_other] self.trust_api.create_trust(trust_id, trust, roles) # Create a client for user_two, scoped to the trust client = self.get_client(self.user_two) ret = client.authenticate(trust_id=trust_id, tenant_id=self.tenant_bar['id']) self.assertTrue(ret) self.assertTrue(client.auth_ref.trust_scoped) self.assertEqual(trust_id, client.auth_ref.trust_id) # Create an ec2 keypair using the trust client impersonating user_foo cred = client.ec2.create(user_id=self.user_foo['id'], tenant_id=self.tenant_bar['id']) credentials, signature = self._generate_user_ec2_credentials( cred.access, cred.secret) credentials['signature'] = signature resp, token = self._send_ec2_auth_request(credentials) self.assertEqual(resp.status_code, 200) self.assertEqual(trust_id, token['access']['trust']['id']) #TODO(shardy) we really want to check the roles and trustee # but because of where the stubbing happens we don't seem to # hit the necessary code in controllers.py _authenticate_token # so although all is OK via a real request, it incorrect in # this test.. def test_ec2_auth_failure(self): from keystoneclient import exceptions as client_exceptions credentials, signature = self._generate_default_user_ec2_credentials() credentials['signature'] = uuid.uuid4().hex self.assertRaises(client_exceptions.Unauthorized, self._send_ec2_auth_request, credentials) def test_ec2_credential_crud(self): creds = self.default_client.ec2.list(user_id=self.user_foo['id']) self.assertEqual(creds, []) cred = self.default_client.ec2.create(user_id=self.user_foo['id'], tenant_id=self.tenant_bar['id']) creds = self.default_client.ec2.list(user_id=self.user_foo['id']) self.assertEqual(creds, [cred]) got = self.default_client.ec2.get(user_id=self.user_foo['id'], access=cred.access) self.assertEqual(cred, got) self.default_client.ec2.delete(user_id=self.user_foo['id'], access=cred.access) creds = self.default_client.ec2.list(user_id=self.user_foo['id']) self.assertEqual(creds, []) def test_ec2_credential_crud_non_admin(self): na_client = self.get_client(self.user_two) creds = na_client.ec2.list(user_id=self.user_two['id']) self.assertEqual(creds, []) cred = na_client.ec2.create(user_id=self.user_two['id'], tenant_id=self.tenant_baz['id']) creds = na_client.ec2.list(user_id=self.user_two['id']) self.assertEqual(creds, [cred]) got = na_client.ec2.get(user_id=self.user_two['id'], access=cred.access) self.assertEqual(cred, got) na_client.ec2.delete(user_id=self.user_two['id'], access=cred.access) creds = na_client.ec2.list(user_id=self.user_two['id']) self.assertEqual(creds, []) def test_ec2_list_credentials(self): cred_1 = self.default_client.ec2.create( user_id=self.user_foo['id'], tenant_id=self.tenant_bar['id']) cred_2 = self.default_client.ec2.create( user_id=self.user_foo['id'], tenant_id=self.tenant_service['id']) cred_3 = self.default_client.ec2.create( user_id=self.user_foo['id'], tenant_id=self.tenant_mtu['id']) two = self.get_client(self.user_two) cred_4 = two.ec2.create(user_id=self.user_two['id'], tenant_id=self.tenant_bar['id']) creds = self.default_client.ec2.list(user_id=self.user_foo['id']) self.assertEqual(len(creds), 3) self.assertEqual(sorted([cred_1, cred_2, cred_3], key=lambda x: x.access), sorted(creds, key=lambda x: x.access)) self.assertNotIn(cred_4, creds) def test_ec2_credentials_create_404(self): from keystoneclient import exceptions as client_exceptions self.assertRaises(client_exceptions.NotFound, self.default_client.ec2.create, user_id=uuid.uuid4().hex, tenant_id=self.tenant_bar['id']) self.assertRaises(client_exceptions.NotFound, self.default_client.ec2.create, user_id=self.user_foo['id'], tenant_id=uuid.uuid4().hex) def test_ec2_credentials_delete_404(self): from keystoneclient import exceptions as client_exceptions self.assertRaises(client_exceptions.NotFound, self.default_client.ec2.delete, user_id=uuid.uuid4().hex, access=uuid.uuid4().hex) def test_ec2_credentials_get_404(self): from keystoneclient import exceptions as client_exceptions self.assertRaises(client_exceptions.NotFound, self.default_client.ec2.get, user_id=uuid.uuid4().hex, access=uuid.uuid4().hex) def test_ec2_credentials_list_404(self): from keystoneclient import exceptions as client_exceptions self.assertRaises(client_exceptions.NotFound, self.default_client.ec2.list, user_id=uuid.uuid4().hex) def test_ec2_credentials_list_user_forbidden(self): from keystoneclient import exceptions as client_exceptions two = self.get_client(self.user_two) self.assertRaises(client_exceptions.Forbidden, two.ec2.list, user_id=self.user_foo['id']) def test_ec2_credentials_get_user_forbidden(self): from keystoneclient import exceptions as client_exceptions cred = self.default_client.ec2.create(user_id=self.user_foo['id'], tenant_id=self.tenant_bar['id']) two = self.get_client(self.user_two) self.assertRaises(client_exceptions.Forbidden, two.ec2.get, user_id=self.user_foo['id'], access=cred.access) self.default_client.ec2.delete(user_id=self.user_foo['id'], access=cred.access) def test_ec2_credentials_delete_user_forbidden(self): from keystoneclient import exceptions as client_exceptions cred = self.default_client.ec2.create(user_id=self.user_foo['id'], tenant_id=self.tenant_bar['id']) two = self.get_client(self.user_two) self.assertRaises(client_exceptions.Forbidden, two.ec2.delete, user_id=self.user_foo['id'], access=cred.access) self.default_client.ec2.delete(user_id=self.user_foo['id'], access=cred.access) def test_endpoint_create_404(self): from keystoneclient import exceptions as client_exceptions client = self.get_client(admin=True) self.assertRaises(client_exceptions.NotFound, client.endpoints.create, region=uuid.uuid4().hex, service_id=uuid.uuid4().hex, publicurl=uuid.uuid4().hex, adminurl=uuid.uuid4().hex, internalurl=uuid.uuid4().hex) def test_endpoint_delete_404(self): from keystoneclient import exceptions as client_exceptions client = self.get_client(admin=True) self.assertRaises(client_exceptions.NotFound, client.endpoints.delete, id=uuid.uuid4().hex) def test_policy_crud(self): # FIXME(dolph): this test was written prior to the v3 implementation of # the client and essentially refers to a non-existent # policy manager in the v2 client. this test needs to be # moved to a test suite running against the v3 api self.skipTest('Written prior to v3 client; needs refactor') from keystoneclient import exceptions as client_exceptions client = self.get_client(admin=True) policy_blob = uuid.uuid4().hex policy_type = uuid.uuid4().hex service = client.services.create( name=uuid.uuid4().hex, service_type=uuid.uuid4().hex, description=uuid.uuid4().hex) endpoint = client.endpoints.create( service_id=service.id, region=uuid.uuid4().hex, adminurl=uuid.uuid4().hex, internalurl=uuid.uuid4().hex, publicurl=uuid.uuid4().hex) # create policy = client.policies.create( blob=policy_blob, type=policy_type, endpoint=endpoint.id) self.assertEqual(policy_blob, policy.policy) self.assertEqual(policy_type, policy.type) self.assertEqual(endpoint.id, policy.endpoint_id) policy = client.policies.get(policy=policy.id) self.assertEqual(policy_blob, policy.policy) self.assertEqual(policy_type, policy.type) self.assertEqual(endpoint.id, policy.endpoint_id) endpoints = [x for x in client.endpoints.list() if x.id == endpoint.id] endpoint = endpoints[0] self.assertEqual(policy_blob, policy.policy) self.assertEqual(policy_type, policy.type) self.assertEqual(endpoint.id, policy.endpoint_id) # update policy_blob = uuid.uuid4().hex policy_type = uuid.uuid4().hex endpoint = client.endpoints.create( service_id=service.id, region=uuid.uuid4().hex, adminurl=uuid.uuid4().hex, internalurl=uuid.uuid4().hex, publicurl=uuid.uuid4().hex) policy = client.policies.update( policy=policy.id, blob=policy_blob, type=policy_type, endpoint=endpoint.id) policy = client.policies.get(policy=policy.id) self.assertEqual(policy_blob, policy.policy) self.assertEqual(policy_type, policy.type) self.assertEqual(endpoint.id, policy.endpoint_id) # delete client.policies.delete(policy=policy.id) self.assertRaises( client_exceptions.NotFound, client.policies.get, policy=policy.id) policies = [x for x in client.policies.list() if x.id == policy.id] self.assertEqual(len(policies), 0) class KcOptTestCase(KcMasterSqlTestCase): # Set KSCTEST_PATH to the keystoneclient directory, then run this test. # # For example, to test your local keystoneclient, # # KSCTEST_PATH=/opt/stack/python-keystoneclient \ # tox -e py27 test_keystoneclient_sql.KcOptTestCase def setUp(self): self.checkout_info = os.environ.get('KSCTEST_PATH') if not self.checkout_info: self.skip('Set KSCTEST_PATH env to test with local client') super(KcOptTestCase, self).setUp()

use oslo_config replace oslo.config

oslo.config to oslo_config

requirements has updated to oslo.conifg 1.6.0

Change-Id: I16b8dc680f8a7697b7fbbd888f5162d924b4c0fe

commit_message:
Added support for secure erase enhanced

Added support for secure erase enhanced option when doing an ATA secure erase.

Also made it prefer the enhanced version if hdparm claims the device
supports it.

Change-Id: I2ce04d0b967d6c176acd40ea10a05bcab5dbf2d0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-python-agent refs/changes/17/153417/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: '\t%(enhanced_erase)s\n' 'enhanced_erase': 'not\tsupported: enhanced erase', 'enhanced_erase': 'not\tsupported: enhanced erase', 'enhanced_erase': 'not\tsupported: enhanced erase', 'enhanced_erase': 'not\tsupported: enhanced erase', 'enhanced_erase': 'not\tsupported: enhanced erase', 'enhanced_erase': 'not\tsupported: enhanced erase', def test_normal_vs_enhanced_security_erase(self): @mock.patch.object(utils, 'execute') def test_security_erase_option(test_case, enhanced_erase_string, expected_option, mocked_execute): hdparm_parameters = { 'supported': '\tsupported', 'enabled': 'not\tenabled', 'frozen': 'not\tfrozen', 'enhanced_erase': enhanced_erase_string, } mocked_execute.side_effect = [ (HDPARM_INFO_TEMPLATE % hdparm_parameters, ''), ('', ''), ('', ''), (HDPARM_INFO_TEMPLATE % hdparm_parameters, ''), ] block_device = hardware.BlockDevice('/dev/sda', 'big', 1073741824, True) test_case.hardware.erase_block_device(block_device) mocked_execute.assert_any_call('hdparm', '--user-master', 'u', expected_option, 'NULL', '/dev/sda') test_security_erase_option(self, '\tsupported: enhanced erase', '--security-erase-enhanced') test_security_erase_option(self, '\tnot\tsupported: enhanced erase', '--security-erase')

added_lines: <para>OpenStack Networking adds a layer of virtualized network services - giving tenants the capability to architect their own virtual networks. These virtualized services are not as currently as mature as their traditional networking counterparts. It is important to be aware of the current state of these virtualized services and what controls may need to be implemented at the virtualized and traditional network boundary.</para>
deleted_lines: <para>OpenStack Networking adds a layer of virtualized network services - giving tenants the capability to architect their own, virtual networks. These virtualized services are not as currently as mature as their traditional networking counterparts. It is important to be aware of the current state of these virtualized services and what controls may need to be implemented at the virtualized and traditional network boundary.</para>

added_lines: <para>Various components, services, and applications within the OpenStack ecosystem or dependencies of OpenStack are implemented and can be configured to use SSL/TLS libraries. The SSL/TLS and HTTP services within OpenStack are typically implemented using OpenSSL which has been validated for FIPS 140-2. However, keep in mind that each application or service can still introduce weaknesses in how they use the OpenSSL libraries.</para>
deleted_lines: <para>Various components, services, and applications within the OpenStack ecosystem or dependencies of OpenStack are implemented and can be configured to use SSL/TLS libraries. The SSL/TLS and HTTP services within OpenStack are typically implemented using OpenSSL which has been proven to be fairly secure and has a module that has been validated for FIPS 140-2. However, keep in mind that each application or service can still introduce weaknesses in how they use the OpenSSL libraries.</para>

commit_message:
Removing non-namespaced oslo_i18n in Juno

This patch removes non-namespaced oslo_i18n in Juno, as oslo_i18n
is not available in Juno.

Closes-Bug: 1420335

commit_message:
Add resource_id None check for deployment deletion

If deployment actions not include 'CREATE', the deployment
resource won't be created, this change add the resource_id
check when deployment deletion to avoid exception happening.

Change-Id: Ib47c3794b66b4fc0bf152b4ba90756de3c494e5a
Closes-Bug: #1406692

commit_message:
Update NIST doc reference to revision 4

Updated the reference to NIST documentation from
revision 3 to revision 4 and added a link to the
NIST doc. Also updated the quotation from that doc
to reflect the text in revision 4.

Change-Id: I4c3603a60824ce2d2bee1639de203c0bc35b3f10
backport: none
Closes-bug: #1419556
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/security-doc refs/changes/05/153905/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para> The privacy and isolation of data has consistently been cited as the primary barrier to cloud adoption over the past few years. Concerns over who owns data in the cloud and whether the cloud operator can be ultimately trusted as a custodian of this data have been significant issues in the past. </para> <para> Numerous OpenStack services maintain data and metadata belonging to tenants or reference tenant information. </para> <para> OpenStack operators should strive to provide a certain level of tenant data disposal assurance. Best practices suggest that the operator sanitize cloud system media (digital and non-digital) prior to disposal, release out of organization control or release for reuse. Sanitization methods should implement an appropriate level of strength and integrity given the specific security domain and sensitivity of the information. </para> <para> "The sanitization process removes information from the media such that the information cannot be retrieved or reconstructed. Sanitization techniques, including clearing, purging, cryptographic erase, and destruction, prevent the disclosure of information to unauthorized individuals when such media is reused or released for disposal." <ulink url="http://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-53r4.pdf">[NIST Special Publication 800-53 Revision 4]</ulink> </para> <para>General data disposal and sanitization guidelines as adopted from NIST recommended security controls. Cloud operators should:</para> <para>Within OpenStack some data may be deleted, but not securely erased in the context of the NIST standards outlined above. This is generally applicable to most or all of the above-defined metadata and information stored in the database. This may be remediated with database and/or system configuration for auto vacuuming and periodic free-space wiping.</para> <para>Specific to various hypervisors is the treatment of instance memory. This behavior is not defined in OpenStack Compute, although it is generally expected of hypervisors that they will make a best effort to scrub memory either upon deletion of an instance, upon creation of an instance, or both.</para> <para>Xen explicitly assigns dedicated memory regions to instances and scrubs data upon the destruction of instances (or domains in Xen parlance). KVM depends more greatly on Linux page management; A complex set of rules related to KVM paging is defined in the <link xlink:href="http://www.linux-kvm.org/page/Memory">KVM documentation</link>.</para> <para>It is important to note that use of the Xen memory balloon feature is likely to result in information disclosure. We strongly recommended to avoid use of this feature.</para> <para>For these and other hypervisors, we recommend referring to hypervisor-specific documentation.</para> <para>Plugins to OpenStack Block Storage will store data in a variety of ways. Many plug-ins are specific to a vendor or technology, whereas others are more DIY solutions around filesystems such as LVM or ZFS. Methods to securely destroy data will vary from one plugin to another, from one vendor's solution to another, and from one filesystem to another.</para>
deleted_lines: <para>The privacy and isolation of data has consistently been cited as the primary barrier to cloud adoption over the past few years. Concerns over who owns data in the cloud and whether the cloud operator can be ultimately trusted as a custodian of this data have been significant issues in the past.</para> <para>Numerous OpenStack services maintain data and metadata belonging to tenants or reference tenant information.</para> <para>OpenStack operators should strive to provide a certain level of tenant data disposal assurance. Best practices suggest that the operator sanitize cloud system media (digital and non-digital) prior to disposal, release out of organization control or release for reuse. Sanitization methods should implement an appropriate level of strength and integrity given the specific security domain and sensitivity of the information.</para> <para>"Sanitization is the process used to remove information from system media such that there is reasonable assurance that the information cannot be retrieved or reconstructed. Sanitization techniques, including clearing, purging, and destroying media information, prevent the disclosure of organizational information to unauthorized individuals when such media is reused or released for disposal." [NIST Special Publication 800-53 Revision 3]</para> <para>General data disposal and sanitization guidelines as adopted from NIST recommended security controls. Cloud operators should:</para> <para>Within OpenStack some data may be deleted, but not securely erased in the context of the NIST standards outlined above. This is generally applicable to most or all of the above-defined metadata and information stored in the database. This may be remediated with database and/or system configuration for auto vacuuming and periodic free-space wiping.</para> <para>Specific to various hypervisors is the treatment of instance memory. This behavior is not defined in OpenStack Compute, although it is generally expected of hypervisors that they will make a best effort to scrub memory either upon deletion of an instance, upon creation of an instance, or both.</para> <para>Xen explicitly assigns dedicated memory regions to instances and scrubs data upon the destruction of instances (or domains in Xen parlance). KVM depends more greatly on Linux page management; A complex set of rules related to KVM paging is defined in the <link xlink:href="http://www.linux-kvm.org/page/Memory">KVM documentation</link>.</para> <para>It is important to note that use of the Xen memory balloon feature is likely to result in information disclosure. We strongly recommended to avoid use of this feature.</para> <para>For these and other hypervisors, we recommend referring to hypervisor-specific documentation.</para> <para>Plugins to OpenStack Block Storage will store data in a variety of ways. Many plug-ins are specific to a vendor or technology, whereas others are more DIY solutions around filesystems such as LVM or ZFS. Methods to securely destroy data will vary from one plugin to another, from one vendor's solution to another, and from one filesystem to another.</para>

commit_message:
Restore lost changes to neutron-vpnaas

Commit f1b505830d97eb22d6188408934bc92df1f38b1c accidentially reverted
the change made in aeb3aa5930e5b3c9757358e42c62a08139e7120d that
moved check-neutron-vpnaas-dsvm-functional from experimental to
check queue (non-voting).

This restores the aeb3aa5930e5b3c9757358e42c62a08139e7120d commit.

Change-Id: I0e0ab8c6423e778d7a6536939cf9d853df616516

commit_message:
Update gabbi to 0.6.0

This provides increased ability to refer to the prior response
in the current response (both strings and json). This is necessary
to effectively traverse JSON APIs but comes at some cost to
readability of the tests.

Change-Id: I51a5c449c0367a3d5949eef852763499e33a6e03
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/01/153301/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Make more blockinfo functions private.

These are not referenced outside of blockinfo (other than for testing):

* update_bdm
* has_default_ephemeral
* get_device_name
* get_config_drive_type
* get_next_disk_info
* is_disk_bus_valid_for_virt
* find_disk_dev_for_disk_bus
* get_dev_count_for_disk_bus
* get_dev_prefix_for_disk_bus
* has_disk_dev
* SUPPORTED_DISK_TYPES
* BOOT_DEV_FOR_TYPE

Change-Id: I8c2e4b1c88f37804673f0e333ac7efc29cc4a100

commit_message:
Fix the rgw apache CI tests

This fixes various issues with the rgw apache CI tests:

* the test did not properly check for success as the curl always exits
with 0, even when the HTTP return code is 401 / unauthorized
* there was a missing dependency to wait until the OSD is ready
* changing the tested versions to be in sync with all other tests.
* cleaning up left over files when uninstalling
* autogenerate the pools

Change-Id: I28dacb1a18e20429f93f2f9996f8196a1d992374

commit_message:
Fix dependency tree to include necessary package ceph

The file /var/lib/ceph/radosgw needs package ceph as a dependency,
because the parent directory /var/lib/ceph is not necessarily present
otherwise.

The cleanest way to achieve that is to make sure all packages tagged
ceph are present.

Change-Id: Ic861e1fb3b3c556961ac8f9026a50863dff7f9e1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ceph refs/changes/85/153885/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Package<| tag == 'ceph' |>

commit_message:
Restart 'statsenderd' after changing Collector IP

In order to use test Collector instance while sending
usage stats during system tests we need to restart
'statsenderd' daemon after changing settings.

Change-Id: I76b1a7162c30d0dfa6556878a8c18811233d376c
Implements: blueprint fuel-stats-test
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-qa refs/changes/47/153947/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #Restart statsenderd in order to apply new settings (Collector address) self.nailgun_actions.force_fuel_stats_sending()
